statement.p:
Consider the infinite Taylor series given by
T(x) =\mathstrut \amp \sum_{k = 1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k \cdot 2^k}(x-1)^k =\mathstrut \amp \frac{1}{1 \cdot 2}(x-1) + \frac{1}{2 \cdot 4}(x-1)^2 + \frac{1}{3 \cdot 8}(x-1)^3 + \cdots + \frac{1}{n \cdot 2^n}(x-1)^n + \cdots .

li.p: As described in the statement of the Ratio Test, let r_n(x) be the ratio of the (n+1)st term of T(x) to the nth term of T(x). Find the simplest formula that you can for r_n(x).
Let r(x) = \lim_{n \to \infty} r_n(x). Evaluate this limit to find the simplest formula you can for r(x).
For what values of x is |r(x)| \lt 1? What does this tell us about T(x) for these x-values?

Let T_{10}(x) be the sum of the first 10 terms of T(x), and let f(x) = \ln(2) - \ln(3-x). Plot f(x) and T_{10}(x) on the same coordinate axes. What do you notice? What does this suggest about the series T(x)?

For r(x) = \lim_{n \to \infty} r_n(x), we observe that
r(x) =\mathstrut \amp \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n}{n+1} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \cdot (x-1) =\mathstrut \amp \frac{1}{2} \cdot (x-1) \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n}{n+1} =\mathstrut \amp \frac{1}{2} \cdot (x-1)

Now we can say that |r(x)| \lt 1 whenever
|\frac{1}{2} \cdot (x-1)| \lt 1 , which implies
|x - 1| \lt 2 . Thus T(x) is guaranteed to converge whenever -1 \lt x \lt 3.

When we plot T_{10}(x) and f(x) = \ln(2) - \ln(3-x) on the interval from 1 \lt x \lt 3, we see that T_{10} and f are nearly indistinguishable for a considerable subset of the interval. This suggests that T(x) is the Taylor serise of f(x) = \ln(2) - \ln(3-x).
